a.g: Certainly has Allah heard the speech of the one who argues with you, [O Muhammad], concerning her husband and directs her complaint to Allah. And Allah hears your dialogue; indeed, Allah is Hearing and Seeing.

Those who pronounce thihar among you [to separate] from their wives - they are not [consequently] their mothers. Their mothers are none but those who gave birth to them. And indeed, they are saying an objectionable statement and a falsehood. But indeed, Allah is Pardoning and Forgiving.

And those who pronounce thihar from their wives and then [wish to] go back on what they said - then [there must be] the freeing of a slave before they touch one another. That is what you are admonished thereby; and Allah is Acquainted with what you do.

And he who does not find [a slave] - then a fast for two months consecutively before they touch one another; and he who is unable - then the feeding of sixty poor persons. That is for you to believe [completely] in Allah and His Messenger; and those are the limits [set by] Allah. And for the disbelievers is a painful punishment.

Indeed, those who oppose Allah and His Messenger are abased as those before them were abased. And We have certainly sent down verses of clear evidence. And for the disbelievers is a humiliating punishment.
On the Day when Allah will resurrect them all and inform them of what they did. Allah had enumerated it, while they forgot it; and Allah is, over all things, Witness.

Indeed, God Almighty says: "On the Day when God will resurrect them all together, then He will inform them of what they did. God has kept account of it, while they have forgotten it; and God is Witness over all things." (58:6) Thus, the possessors of insight [arbab al-basa'ir] from among the servants recognized that God Almighty lies in wait for them, and that they will be scrutinized in the Reckoning [hisab] and held accountable for the weight of an atom [mithqal al-dharr] from their passing thoughts [khawatir] and glances [lahazat]. They became certain [tahaqqu] that nothing will save them from these perils except adhering to self-reckoning [muhasaba] and sincere self-watchfulness [muraqaba], and holding the soul [nafs] to account for every breath [anfas] and movement [harakat], and reckoning with it for every passing thought [khawatir] and glance [lahazat]. For whoever holds his soul to account before he is held to account, his reckoning on the Day of Standing [al-qiyamah] will be lightened, his answer will be present when questioned, and his return [ma'ab] and outcome [manqalib] will be good. And whoever does not hold his soul to account, his regrets [hasrat] will be prolonged, his halts in the plains of the Resurrection [arassat al-qiyamah] will be extended, and his misdeeds [sayyi'at] will lead him to disgrace and contempt. When this was unveiled [inkashafa] to them, they knew that nothing would save them from it except obedience to God, and He has commanded them with patience [sabr] and vigilant steadfastness [murabata].

a.g: Have you not considered that Allah knows what is in the heavens and what is on the earth? There is in no private conversation three but that He is the fourth of them, nor are there five but that He is the sixth of them - and no less than that and no more except that He is with them [in knowledge] wherever they are. Then He will inform them of what they did, on the Day of Resurrection. Indeed Allah is, of all things, Knowing.

Have you not considered those who were forbidden from private conversation, then they return to that which they were forbidden and converse among themselves about sin and aggression and disobedience to the Messenger? And when they come to you, they greet you with that [word] by which Allah does not greet you and say among themselves, "Why does Allah not punish us for what we say?" Sufficient for them is Hell, which they will [enter to] burn, and wretched is the destination.

Indeed, God the Exalted answered their statement, "Hell is sufficient for them; they will enter it, and wretched is the destination." And at times they look upon the believersâ€”who are poor, disheveled, and dustyâ€”and they scorn them and belittle them, saying, "Are these the ones whom God has favored among us?" and they say, "If it were any good, they would not have preceded us to it." And the structure of the syllogism [qiyas] they have arranged in their hearts [qulub] is that they say: God has been good to us with the comfort of the world [dunya], and every benefactor is a lover, and every lover will also be good in the future, as the poet said: 'God has been good in what has passed, and thus He will be good in what remains.' And they only analogize the future to the past based on honor [karamah] and love, for they say: Were I not honorable and beloved to God, He would not have been good to me. The deception [talbis] lies beneath their assumption that every benefactor is a lover; nay, beneath their assumption that His bestowing upon them in the world [dunya] is a benefaction. Thus, they are deluded concerning God, for they suppose they are honorable to Him based on evidence that does not indicate honor [karamah]; rather, in the sight of those of insight [basirah], it indicates disgrace.

a.g: O you who have believed, when you converse privately, do not converse about sin and aggression and disobedience to the Messenger but converse about righteousness and piety. And fear Allah, to whom you will be gathered.
Private conversation is only from Satan that he may grieve those who have believed, but he will not harm them at all except by permission of Allah. And upon Allah let the believers rely.

O you who have believed, when you are told, "Space yourselves" in assemblies, then make space; Allah will make space for you. And when you are told, "Arise," then arise; Allah will raise those who have believed among you and those who were given knowledge, by degrees. And Allah is Acquainted with what you do.

And indeed, the purpose of all acts of obedience [ta'at] and the works of the limbs is the purification [tasfiya] of the heart [qalb], its refinement [tazkiya], and its polishing. "He has succeeded who purifies it." And the purpose of its refinement is the attainment of the lights of faith [anwar al-iman] within itâ€”I mean the shining forth of the light of knowledge [nur al-ma'rifa]. And this is what is intended by His, the Exalted's, saying: "So whoever Allah wills to guide, He expands his breast to Islam. Is he whose breast Allah has expanded to Islam, then he is upon a light from his Lord?" Yes, this manifestation [tajalli] and this faith [iman] have three levels. The first level is the faith of the common people [iman al-'awamm], and it is the faith of pure imitation [taqlid]. The second is the faith of the theologians [iman al-mutakallimin], and it is mixed with a kind of rational deduction [istidlal], and its degree is close to the degree of the faith of the common people. The third is the faith of the knowers [iman al-'arifin], and it is what is witnessed [mushahad] by the light of certainty [nur al-yaqin]. And they also differ according to the measures of knowledge [maqadir al-'ulum] and the degrees of unveiling [darajat al-kashf]. As for the degrees of unveiling, its example is that one sees Zayd in the courtyard from nearby and in the open courtyard at the time of the sun's shining, so his perception of him is complete. Another perceives him in a room, or from a distance, or at the time of dusk, so he appears to him in his form such that he is certain [yastayqinu] it is him, but the subtleties [daqaiq] and hidden aspects [khafaya] of his form do not appear to his inner self [nafs]. And the like of this is conceivable in the disparity of witnessing [mushahada] divine matters. As for the measures of knowledge, it is that one sees in the courtyard Zayd, 'Amr, and Bakr, and another besides that, while another sees only Zayd. So the knowledge [ma'rifa] of that increases with the abundance of known things [ma'lumat], inevitably. This is the state of the heart [qalb] in relation to the sciences [al-'ulum].
